Award.AwardTitle: ATD: Estimation and Anomaly Detection for high-dimensional Data, Maps and Dynamic Processes
Award.AbstractNarration:
The project focuses on the analysis of collections of regular, hyperspectral, LiDAR, and thermal images, and multi-modal data sets, both in terms of detection of anomalies and classification tasks. The input data (such as images, spectra, etc.) for many threat detection problems is typically high-dimensional, corrupted by noise, and subject to nonlinear transformations due to environmental conditions. Automatic threat detection problems typically face the fundamental curse of dimensionality: to achieve a target level of accuracy, the number of observations required is exponential in the dimension of the data. This work focuses on the automated discovery of low-dimensional representations of the data, or at least of those features of the data that are sufficient to perform the task at hand. These representations will enable high statistical and computational performance in the above tasks even with a relatively small amount of data. The project will also focus on automatically modeling and learning interaction rules in interacting agent systems.

This project entails an overarching program of research aimed at detecting and exploiting intrinsic low-dimensionality and estimating low-dimensional models for data and certain types of high-dimensional data and agent-based systems. Low-dimensional probabilistic models for high-dimensional data, arising from Hyper-Spectral Imaging (HSI), LiDAR, and Near-Infrad/Night-Vision cameras, will be constructed, enabling efficient data encoding and decoding, statistical models for detecting background noise versus signals of interest, and anomaly detection. Novel techniques for understanding dependencies across multiple sensor modalities by studying maps in high-dimensions between data collected by different sensors will be developed and tested on a variety of multi-modal data sets. Novel machine learning techniques for learning from agent systems with unknown influence functions will be developed.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project studied several fundamental statistical and machine learning problems that have applications to both thread detection and beyond. We may group our research endeavours in 3 directions. In the first direction, we developed techniques for provably and efficiently (both in a statistical and in a computational sense) learn parsimonious representations for high-dimensional data. This enables multiple applications, from data compression to the solution of certain statistical problems (e.g. predictions from data) to be more efficient, both in computational and statistical terms. A second direction focused on the deveopment of novel algorithms for finding clusters in data, i.e. automatically finding groupings of similar data points in large, high-dimensional data set. This type of tasks is used in a variety of scientific disciplines (from biology to computer science) and applications (from finding groups of co-regulated genes to agglomerating news articles and discovering topics in document corpora). We introduced several novel techniques which are highly rebost to data corruption, and that can be implemented with fast algorithms. We demonstrated applications to the automatic segmentation of hyperspectral images (e.g. used to monitor in crop health, or analyze satallite imagery), and showed we achieve state-of-art results. In the third line of research, we developed algorithms for learning interaction laws in physical or agent-based systems, that require a very small (in fact, optimally small) number of observations, in order to discover the underlying laws, with minimal no a priori information on the form of such laws. This can enable scientific discovery in systems of interest (e.g. in physics or biology or social sciences), and at the same time enable accurate predictions, even of large scale and large-time complex emergent behaviors in such systems, and the detection of changes or anomalous behavior.

The results above have been published in high quality publications, with wide scientific audiences, in various scientific disciplines (including mathematics, computer science, engineering), and presented both in in-person workshops and conferences, and online in widely attended, and recorded and publicly available, online seminars. Code implementing the algorithms underlying the research have also been produced and made publicly available, to facilitate the use and further development by researchers and practitioners.
